BR_text.BRdescription:
When I load this model in other software it appears correctly as this:
 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/590151/73598370-5e1ab280-44ec-11ea-9491-f60c69e64435.png></denchmark-link>
 
 But with Open3D the texture is all messaged up:
 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/590151/73598354-33305e80-44ec-11ea-8797-b55a55020f91.png></denchmark-link>
 
 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/590151/73598355-3a576c80-44ec-11ea-9960-fa70fde3551b.png></denchmark-link>
 
 Here is the code I'm using:
 <denchmark-code>import open3d as o3d
 
 def visualize(mesh):
     vis = o3d.visualization.Visualizer()
     vis.create_window()
     vis.add_geometry(mesh)
     vis.run()
     vis.destroy_window()
 
 def main():
     mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh("scene_mesh_decimated_textured.obj")
     visualize(mesh)
 
 main()
 </denchmark-code>
 
 And here is the model and texture:
 <denchmark-link:https://www.dropbox.com/s/xm0sun3hoijwbjf/Archive.zip?dl=0>https://www.dropbox.com/s/xm0sun3hoijwbjf/Archive.zip?dl=0</denchmark-link>

comments_1.comment_text:
The obj file you shared the multiple materials (8 texture maps and materials). I think the following line would affect the issue
 
 
 <denchmark-link:https://github.com/theNded>@theNded</denchmark-link>
  Is this related to the fact that the textured mesh only can store a single texture map?
 I also presume the issue comes from an inaccurate decoding UV coordinate.

comments_3.comment_text: It seems that Wei will be the champion for this task. Thanks Wei!

comments_9.comment_text:
Hi,
 I’m working with the Python version Open3D 0.10.0.1. Using MeshLab my example mesh is showed like this
 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42244318/90468149-ea38a400-e0e3-11ea-94bd-97abe48a9a78.jpg></denchmark-link>
 
 But when I load and display the mesh with Open3D the window goes blank
 <denchmark-link:https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/42244318/90468290-3be12e80-e0e4-11ea-800b-9fac8e281ca9.jpg></denchmark-link>
 
 My code goes like this:
 mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh(“path/to/mesh”) o3d.visualization.draw_geometries([mesh]) 
 I can’t tell if I’m doing something wrong or if it is an issue. Can you please help me??!!!
 I’m gonna let this link below in case you wanna test it
 <denchmark-link:url>https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1Ik2Blbkhm3w8fTeXxw_3gBKoeg4iBncS?usp=sharing</denchmark-link>

comments_10.comment_text: I think this may not be a blank window, but the mesh is all white, you can try assigning a different color for the mesh. . Then see what happens <denchmark-link:https://github.com/ArlenisChS>@ArlenisChS</denchmark-link>

comments_11.comment_text:
I think this may not be a blank window, but the mesh is all white, you can try assigning a different color for the mesh. mesh.paint_uniform_color([0.5, 0.5, 0.5]. Then see what happens @ArlenisChS
 
 Oh yes, sorry for not putting what was happening. I was painting the mesh with MeshLab and when saving it into a .ply the color seem to be set to white. It seems like I needed to save the mesh activating some flags, wish I did it and now it works. Thanks for the help!! 🤗

comments_12.comment_text:
Hi,
 I am trying to load the attached .obj and corresponding .mtl files. However, I am getting the following warning message:
 <denchmark-code>[Open3D WARNING] Read OBJ failed: Both `d` and `Tr` parameters defined for "m15". Use the value of `d` for dissolve (line 88 in .mtl.)
 Both `d` and `Tr` parameters defined for "m17". Use the value of `d` for dissolve (line 103 in .mtl.)
 Both `d` and `Tr` parameters defined for "m19". Use the value of `d` for dissolve (line 118 in .mtl.)
 
 
 Process finished with exit code 139 (interrupted by signal 11: SIGSEGV)
 </denchmark-code>
 
 Then I've manually removed the Tr values but it still segfaults without any output error.
 Any idea what could be wrong?
 The code I am using is the following:
 <denchmark-code>    os.chdir("./model/house/0004d52d1aeeb8ae6de39d6bd993e992/")
     mesh = o3d.io.read_triangle_mesh("./house_room2.obj",print_progress = True)
     o3d.visualization.draw_geometries([mesh])
 </denchmark-code>
 
 <denchmark-link:https://github.com/intel-isl/Open3D/files/5175472/model.zip>model.zip</denchmark-link>
